metadata.title: A dinuclear triazenido–copper complex: A new molecular electro-catalyst for generating hydrogen from acetic acid or water
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

Conditions: 1.0M buffer solution, pH 6, GC working electrode (1.25cm2), Ag/AgCl in saturated KCl reference electrode, Pt wire counter electrode, 72h. A dinuclear triazenido–copper complex: A new molecular electro-catalyst for generating hydrogen from acetic acid or water Jie-Ping Cao Ting Fang Zhuo-Qiang Wang Yan-Wei Ren ⁎ Shuzhong Zhan ⁎ College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 610640, China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, South China University of Technology Guangzhou 610640 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 136 50761066; fax: +86 20 87112053. Graphical abstract The reaction of 1,3-bis[(4-chloro)benzene]triazene (HL) and CuCl2·2H2O affords a dinuclear triazenido–copper(II) complex [Cu2L4(NCCH3)] (1), a new molecular electrocatalyst, which has been determined by X-ray crystallography. Electrochemical studies show that complex 1 can catalyze hydrogen evolution from acetic acid or water. Turnover frequency (TOF) reaches a maximum of 43 (in DMF) and 174 (in phosphate buffer, pH 6) moles of hydrogen per mole of catalyst per hour, respectively. Sustained proton reduction catalysis occurs at glassy carbon (GC) electrode to give H2 over a 72h electrolysis period and no observable decomposition of the catalyst. Keywords Triazenido–copper(II) complex Molecular electro-catalyst Hydrogen evolution 1 Introduction The ability to store and recover secure, clean, sustainable energy is arguably the most important scientific and technical challenge facing humanity in the 21st century. Chemical fuels are ideal in this context since chemical bonds have high energy density. And hydrogen has attracted considerable attention as an alternative chemical fuel vector. In this regard, on a mid- to long-term basis, it is urgent to provide an appealing approach toward generating and storing hydrogen in a more sustainable manner [1–3]. Hydrogenase enzymes [4,5] can efficiently catalyze both the production and the oxidation of hydrogen using earth-abundant metals (nickel and iron). Structural studies have established that the FeFe-hydrogenases function by combining cofactors that couple acid–base and redox reactions mediated by the diiron dithilate core and its cofactors (Fig. 1 ) [4,6,7]. The structural studies have led to the suggestion that a basic nitrogen or oxygen atom may be incorporated into the backbone of the dithiolate ligand [4,8–10]. The amine [11] or oxygen [12] cofactor is proposed to facilitate the cleavage/formation of the hydrogen–hydrogen bond and the transfer of protons to and from the distal metal centre [12]. However, enzymes are difficult to obtain in sufficient amounts to adapt for commercial applications and their stability is often limited outside of their native environment [4,5,13]. These considerations have led to the development of molecular catalysts employing more abundant metals, and several complexes that contain nickel, iron or cobalt [4,12,14–21] have been developed as electrocatalysts for the production of hydrogen. However, an important fundamental question for the enzymes that remains to be answered is the precise role of the proposed pendant base in hydrogen oxidation and production. And most of the diiron dithiolate complexes have been electrochemically investigated by using organic acids in organic solvents. With this in mind, our group has tried to probe new electro-catalysts through the synthesis of dinuclear complexes with triazenido ligands [22,23]. The central nitrogen of the triazenido ligand imparts greater basicity on the [NNN]− relative to the neutral nitrogen, making the triazenido more electron donating, amenable to binding to H+ and hydrogen production. To the best of our knowledge, there is as yet no report on the use of complexes of the first-row transition metals with triazenido ligands to electrocatalyze hydrogen evolution. Here we present the synthesis, structure and properties of a new dinuclear triazenido–copper(II) complex [Cu2L4(NCCH3)] 1, that can catalyze hydrogen evolution from acetic acid or water. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and physical measurements All commercially available reagents were used without further purification. Cyclic voltammograms were obtained on a CHI-600E electrochemical analyzer under oxygen-free conditions using a three-electrode cell in which a glassy carbon electrode GC, 1mm in diameter) was the working electrode, a saturated Ag/AgNO3 electrode was the reference electrode, and platinum wire was the auxiliary electrode. A ferrocenium/ferrocene couple was used as an internal standard and E 1/2 of the ferrocenium/ferrocene (FeCP2 +/0) couple under the experimental condition was 0.47V. 0.1M [(n-Bu)4N]ClO4 was used as the supporting electrolyte. Acetic acid was added by syringe. Controlled-potential electrolysis (CPE) in DMF was conducted using an air-tight glass double compartment cell separated by a glass frit. The working compartment was fitted with a glassy carbon plate and a Ag/AgNO3 reference electrode. The auxiliary compartment was fitted with a Pt gauze electrode. The working compartment was filled with 50mL of 80mM acetic acid in a 0.1M [(n-Bu4N)]ClO4 DMF solution, while the auxiliary compartment was filled with 35mL of 0.1M [(n-Bu4N)]ClO4 DMF solution, resulting in equal solution levels in both compartments. Both compartments were sparged for 30min with N2 and cyclic voltammograms were recorded as controls. Complex 1 (0.34μM) was then added and a cyclic voltammogram was recorded. CPE in aqueous media was also conducted using an air-tight glass double compartment cell separated by a glass frit. The working compartment was fitted with a glassy carbon plate and a Ag/AgCl reference electrode. The auxiliary compartment was fitted with a Pt gauze electrode. The working compartment was filled with 50mL of 0.25M phosphate buffer solution at different pH values containing 0.1M KCl of the supporting electrolyte, while the auxiliary compartment was filled with 35mL phosphate buffer. Both compartments were sparged for 30min with N2 and cyclic voltammograms were recorded as controls. Complex 1 (0.34μM) was then added and a cyclic voltammogram was recorded. After electrolysis under a nitrogen atmosphere, a 0.5mL aliquot of the headspace was removed and replaced with 0.5mL of CH4. A sample of the headspace was injected into the gas chromatograph (GC) (Fig. S11). GC experiments were carried out with an Agilent Technologies 7890A gas chromatography instrument. UV–vis spectra were recorded on a U-3900H spectrophotometer by using a cryostatted optically semi-transparent thin-layer electro-synthetic (OSTTLE) cell. 2.2 Synthesis of 1,3-bis[(4-chloro)benzene]triazene (HL) A sodium nitrite aqueous solution (15%) was added dropwise to a mixed solution of 4-chloroaniline (10mmol) in water (5mL) and 1mol/L of HCl (30mL) under stirring at 0°C. Later, an equal amount of 4-chloroaniline in ethanol was added with continuous stirring. The resulting solution was neutralized with sodium acetate (15%), affording yellow precipitate which was filtered, and dried under vacuum (71%). Re-crystallization from ethyl acetate gave yellow crystals. The yield was 71%. Calcd for C12H9Cl2N3: C, 54.16; H, 3.41; N, 15.79. Found: C, 54.65; H, 3.40; N, 15.37. 1H NMR (400MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.37 (s, 1H), 7.36–7.20 (m, 8H). 13C NMR (100MHz, CDCl3) δ 143.45, 130.73, 129.43, 119.11 (Figs. S1 and S2). 2.3 Synthesis of complex 1 To a solution of HL (0.28g, 1mmol) and triethylamine (0.10g, 1mmol) in acetonitrile/tetrahydrofuran (20mL, 1:1), CuCl2·2H2O (0.17g, 1.0mmol) was added and the mixture was stirred for 15min. The solution was allowed to evaporate, affording black crystals, which were collected and dried in vacuo (0.74, 60.0%). Calcd for C50H35Cl8Cu2N13: C, 48.88; H, 2.87; N, 14.82. Found: C, 48.91; H, 2.88; N, 14.86. UV–vis [DMF, λ max (nm), ɛ (L/mol/cm)]: 242 (9.68×103), 348 (1.39×104). 2.4 Crystal structure determination The X-ray analysis of 1 was carried out with a Bruker SMART CCD area detector using graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å) at room temperature. All empirical absorption corrections were applied by using the SADABS program [24]. The structure was solved using direct methods and the corresponding non-hydrogen atoms are refined anisotropically. All the hydrogen atoms of the ligands were placed in calculated positions with fixed isotropic thermal parameters and included in the structure factor calculations in the final stage of full-matrix least-squares refinement. All calculations were performed using the SHELXTL computer program [25]. Crystallographic data for complex 1 are given in Table S1 and selected bond lengths are listed in Table S2. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure analysis In the presence of Et3N, the reaction of ligand HL and CuCl2·2H2O affords brown crystals of complex 1 in 60.0% yield. As shown in Fig. 2 , the structure of complex 1 consists of two copper centres bridged by four triazenido ligands. Two copper centres present the different coordination environments, Cu1 is four-coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from four anionic ligands (L−) and Cu2 is five-coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from L− and one nitrogen atom from acetonitrile molecule. The CuN bond distances of triazenido ligands fall in the range 2.0256(19)–2.0777(19)Å, and the distance between copper and nitrogen atom of acetonitrile is 2.165(4)Å. The CuCu distance (2.5016(8)Å) is longer than that found in Cu2(dpt)4 (2.441Å) [26], but shorter than that in tetra-bridged copper(II) dimer Cu2(OAc)4 (2.616Å) [27]. 3.2 Cyclic voltammetry studies Cyclic voltammogram of complex 1 in DMF exhibits two reversible couples at −1.72 and 0.22V versus Ag/AgNO3 (Fig. 3 ). We assign the reversible couples to the metal-centred CuI/0 and CuI/II processes, respectively. As observed in Fig. 4 , the current response of the redox events at −1.72V versus Ag/AgNO3 shows a linear dependence on the square root of the scan rate, which is an indicative of a diffusion-controlled process, with the electrochemically active species freely diffusing in the solution. Such distinctive potential prompted possible usage of this complex as an electrocatalyst for hydrogen evolution. 3.3 Catalytic hydrogen evolution in DMF To determine possible electrocatalytic activity of this complex, cyclic voltammograms of complex 1 were recorded in the presence of acetic acid in DMF. Fig. 5 shows a systematic in i cat observed near −0.95V with increasing acid concentration from 7.2 to 35.0mM. This rise in current can be attributed to the catalytic generation of H2 from acetic acid [28]. Reduction potentials of complex 1 slightly move to more anodic values with the sequential increments of acid concentration. Based on Eq. (1) [28], this reduction occurred at overpotential of 220mV. (1) E HA ⊙ = E H ⊙ + − 2.303 R T F p K aHA A number of control experiments were carried out to verify that complex 1 is responsible for the catalysis. In particular, acetic acid, the free ligand, CuCl2·2H2O, and the mixture of the free ligand and CuCl2·2H2O were each measured under identical conditions. As can be seen in Figs. S3–S6, the catalytic competency achieved with 1 is not matched by just ligand, CuCl2·2H2O, or the mixture of the free ligand and CuCl2·2H2O, as might arise from dissociation of the ligand, nor can it be accomplished with the ligand bound to a redox-inactive metal. Thus, a combination of the redox-active copper ion and the ligand is essential for catalytic activity. Further evidence for the electro-catalytic activity was obtained by bulk electrolysis of a DMF solution of complex 1 (0.34μM) with acetic acid (80mM). Fig. 6 shows the charge of bulk electrolysis of solution containing complex 1 in presence of acetic acid, the charge significantly increased when the applied potential was set to more negative, accompanying gas bubble appeared on the electrode (Fig. S7). When an applied potential was −1.47V versus Ag/AgNO3, the maximum charge reached 105mC during 2min of electrolysis. Controlled-potential electrolysis (CPE) experiment under the same potential with a catalyst-free solution only gave a charge of 10mC (Fig. S8), showing that this complex does serve for effective hydrogen production under such conditions. This study suggested that 1 is capable of catalyzing the reduction of protons from acid. Assuming every catalyst molecule was distributed on the electrode surface and every electron was used for the reduction of protons. According to Eq. (2) [29], we calculated TOF for the catalyst reaching a maximum of 43 moles of hydrogen per mole of catalyst per hour (Fig. S9 and Fig. 7 ). (2) TOF = Δ C F × n 1 × n 2 × t where, ΔC is charge from catalyst solution during CPE minus charge from solution without catalyst during CPE, F is Faraday's constant, n 1 is mol of electrons required to generate a mol of H2, n 2 is mol of catalyst in solution, t is duration of electrolysis. 3.4 Catalytic hydrogen evolution in aqueous media Inspired by DuBois group's work [30,31], we also tried to explore the catalytic hydrogen evolution in aqueous media, a much more attractive medium for the sustainable generation of hydrogen. CVs were conducted in phosphate buffers at different pH values. As shown in Fig. 8 , at pH 7.0, in the absence of complex 1, a catalytic current was not apparent until a potential of −1.45V versus Ag/AgCl was attained. With addition of complex 1, the onset of catalytic current was observed at about −1.25V versus Ag/AgCl, and the current strength increased significantly with increasing concentrations of complex 1 from 0.00 to 12.8μM. When concentration of complex 1 reached 12.8μM, the potential (−1.12V) and current strength did not change at all. The potential moved positive for about 330mV compared to that in the absence of complex 1. This study suggested that 1 can also catalyze the reduction of protons from water. Based on Eq. (1) [28], complex 1 shows an overpotential of 776mV (pH 4.0), 628mV (pH 6.0), 639mV (pH 7.0) and 779mV (pH 8.0), respectively. Catalytic hydrogen production can also be achieved with complex 1 in buffer. Fig. 9 shows the total charge of bulk electrolysis of complex 1 at different pH values. H2 production can be observed at all the pH values studied (4 to 8). When the applied potential was −1.47V versus Ag/AgCl at pH 6.0, the maximum charge was only 49mC during 2min of electrolysis in absence of complex 1 (Fig. S10). Under the same conditions, the charge reached 435mC with addition of complex 1, accompanying the formation of a large amount of gas bubbles, which was confirmed to be H2 by GC analysis (Fig. S11). Based on Eq. (2), TOF for electrocatalytic hydrogen production by complex 1 is 69 (pH 4.0), 174 (pH 6.0), 82 (pH 7.0) and 35 (pH 8.0) moles of hydrogen per mole of catalyst per hour, respectively (Fig. 10 ). At pH 6, TOF reached the maximum value of 174 moles of hydrogen per mole of catalyst per hour, indicating the catalyst shows a better catalytic efficiency under a weak acidic environment. 3.5 Investigation of the stability and durability of complex 1 We used UV–vis spectra to investigate the stability of complex 1 by employing an optically semi-transparent thin layer electrode. As shown in Fig. 11 , the electrochemical reduction of complex 1 at −1.47V versus Ag/AgCl results in one new absorption appeared at 330 (pH 4) and 354 (pH 8)nm, respectively, over an electrolysis period of 1h. At pH 6 and pH 7, the intensity of the absorption band at 348nm slightly decreases, but the peak position does not change, indicating the catalyst is stable in a weak acid or weak base environment. This is also in accordance with the results as revealed by CPE that complex 1 shows a better catalytic efficiency under a weak acidic environment. The durability of the catalyst was assessed in an extended CPE experiment performed in a 1.0M buffer at pH 6. To ensure a rapid turnover rate during the electrolysis, a potential of −1.47V versus Ag/AgCl was employed for the measurement. As depicted in Fig. 12 , the catalyst affords a robust and essentially linear charge build-up over time, with no substantial loss in activity over the course of 72h. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have successfully constructed a copper–triazenido complex 1. Electrochemical studies show that 1 can not only generate dihydrogen from acetic acid but also from water. This discovery has established a new chemical paradigm for creating reduction catalysts that are highly active and robust in both organic and aqueous media. Ongoing efforts are focused on modifying triazenido ligands and related complexes to further facilitate new functional studies, with special emphasis on chemistry relevant to sustainable energy cycles. coredata.dc:description: The reaction of 1,3-bis[(4-chloro)benzene]triazene (HL) and CuCl2·2H2O affords a dinuclear triazenido–copper(II) complex [Cu2L4(NCCH3)] (1), a new molecular electrocatalyst, which has been determined by X-ray crystallography. Electrochemical studies show that complex 1 can catalyze hydrogen evolution from acetic acid or water. Turnover frequency (TOF) reaches a maximum of 43 (in DMF) and 174 (in phosphate buffer, pH 6) moles of hydrogen per mole of catalyst per hour, respectively. Sustained proton reduction catalysis occurs at glassy carbon (GC) electrode to give H2 over a 72h electrolysis period and no observable decomposition of the catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: A dinuclear triazenido–copper complex: A new molecular electro-catalyst for generating hydrogen from acetic acid or water
